title: PowerShell Foundations for Cyber Practitioners
subtitle: Cmdlets, objects, and automation habits for Windows environments
learning_objectives: Describe how PowerShell differs from CMD/Bash and why it returns .NET objects
Use `Get-Help`, `Get-Command`, and `Get-Member` to explore cmdlets safely
Build pipelines that filter, sort, and export structured data
Configure execution policy responsibly and explain script signing options
Establish PowerShell remoting with least privilege and session transcripts
Document scripts with comments, transcripts, and version control

content_blocks.title: Think in Objects

content.text: PowerShell rewards curiosity. Treat every command as an opportunity to shape objects instead of parsing text. Ask: *What object am I working with and how can I view it safely?*

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: PowerShell works with objects—explore before you execute.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: SOC analysts lean on PowerShell to inventory hosts, collect logs, and respond to incidents. Mastering the basics prevents costly mistakes later.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: Which Windows task would be easier if you could query structured objects instead of scraping text?

content_blocks.title: POWERS Habit

content.text:
### POWERS
- **P**ipeline objects, not strings
- **O**bserve with `Get-Help` and `Get-Member`
- **W**ork via providers (FileSystem, Registry)
- **E**xecution policy awareness
- **R**emoting with just-enough rights
- **S**cripts documented and versioned

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: Follow POWERS every session to stay safe and productive.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: Teams that adopt POWERS reduce incidents caused by unsafe scripts or over-privileged remoting.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: Which POWERS habit do you already follow, and which will you practise this week?

content_blocks.title: Discovery Cmdlets Cheat Sheet

content.text:
- Explore: `Get-Command`, `Get-Help`, `Get-Member`
- Filesystem: `Get-ChildItem`, `Test-Path`, `Copy-Item`
- Processes & Services: `Get-Process`, `Get-Service`, `Stop-Process`
- Filter & Format: `Where-Object`, `Select-Object`, `Format-Table`, `Export-Csv`

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: Start with discovery commands before altering anything.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: Incident responders use these cmdlets to triage systems quickly and safely.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: Which discovery cmdlet will you add to your daily workflow?

content_blocks.title: Field Example: SOC Onboarding

content.text: A financial SOC halved analyst onboarding time by giving new hires a PowerShell foundations lab and the POWERS checklist. Analysts now pull host inventories and export logs with reusable scripts instead of manual clicks.

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: A small investment in PowerShell basics yields big operational gains.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: Organisations track productivity improvements when analysts master essential cmdlets.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: Which repetitive Windows task will you automate first?

content_blocks.title: Guided Lab: Build Your First Toolkit

content.text:
1. Launch PowerShell and explore with `Get-Help`, `Get-Command`, and `Get-Member`.
2. Write a script that lists services, filters for those stopped, and exports to CSV.
3. Set execution policy to `RemoteSigned` temporarily, note why, then revert.
4. Open a lab remoting session using a least-privileged account and run your script.
5. Enable transcription, review the log, and commit the script with comments to version control.

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: Practise discovery, scripting, safety, and documentation end-to-end in a lab.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: This mirrors the workflow analysts follow when triaging endpoints remotely.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: What hurdles did you encounter during the lab, and how will you overcome them next time?

content_blocks.title: Teach Back

content.text:
### Teach Back
- Explain the POWERS mnemonic to a teammate.
- Share your service inventory script, highlighting safety measures.
- Schedule a follow-up in 2 weeks to discuss what you automated next.

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: Teaching someone else locks in your knowledge and builds team muscle.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: Teams that run informal teach-backs see faster adoption of new tooling.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: Who will you teach and how will you capture their feedback?

post_assessment.question: What is the primary reason PowerShell pipelines are powerful for security work?
options: They pass rich .NET objects that can be filtered, sorted, and exported cleanly
post_assessment.explanation: Cmdlets produce objects instead of text, so you can manipulate structured data without fragile parsing.

post_assessment.question: How should you change execution policy when testing scripts?
options: Temporarily adjust it (e.g., RemoteSigned), document the reason, and revert afterward
Disable it completely via the Registry
Execution policy does not affect script safety
post_assessment.explanation: Execution policy helps control script trust. Adjust it only as needed, document the change, and revert to a safer setting once finished.

post_assessment.question: What is the safest way to learn a new cmdlet?
options: Use `Get-Help`, `Get-Member`, and `-WhatIf` in a lab before making changes
Download random scripts from the internet
post_assessment.explanation: Always explore cmdlets in a lab with help and `-WhatIf` so you understand the impact before touching production systems.
